urn:contentItem:6D7H-SH41-DXG5-Y1B4-00000-00Dairy industry diligence rewarded for emission control efforts2024-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:44:12ZLexisNexisARTICLEDairy industry diligence rewarded for emission control effortsBruce Derksen

A ‘sense of duty’ rural mindset steered by public pressure drives the momentum of emission reduction strategies in the North American dairy industry. While much is still to be learnt, and many hurdles scaled, constructive methods are making critical advances.

North American-based dairy activities inevitably result in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from three distinct sources no matter the level of preventive care. These sources include methane emissions from ruminant enteric fermentation, anaerobic decomposition of manure pits and lagoons, nitrous oxide emissions from fertiliser applications, organic soil cultivation, and crop residue decay.

Since most dairy emissions originate from animals and manure storage, the industry has expended vast efforts into reduction methods including improving how cattle are managed, feed variation availability, and more recently incorporating feed additives specifically designed to decrease enteric emissions.

Some operations are turning to anaerobic digesters (ADs) to address manure storage and management. Manure is collected and placed into these digesters which transform methane into biogas.

The drive for improvement

Farm proximity to heavily populated areas has driven outside interest in dairy industry controls as unwanted odours are a prominent issue for the average urbanite says Doug Reinemann, Professor of Biological Systems Engineering at UW-Madison. “Public perception and the social license to practice dairy farming near population centres will continue to encourage farmers to address this issue,” Reinemann says. “Of course, this depends on location, but these pressures are real and will drive controls including the adoption of more anaerobic digesters.”

He says ADs are the most effective method of reducing storage emissions and generating electricity from biogas. This technology essentially eliminates manure as a source while producing green energy.

Reinemann notes methane from manure accounts for roughly one-quarter of a farm’s GHG emissions which an AD can eliminate. When producing renewable energy, up to one-third is slashed by a digester.

Wisconsin currently boasts the most ADs of any state. 20 years ago, green energy prices were available for biogas-generated electricity. This is no longer an option in most parts of the country, hindering AD uptakes. Reinemann estimates only 5 to 10% of US dairies currently run a digester.

“They make a huge impact, but the main reason for a lack of adoption is they aren’t economically feasible on a small dairy especially when grazing is part of the feed management system,” he says. “Manure on grazing land can’t be collected. The technology is sound but unfortunately, it’s mostly larger farms capitalising.”

An extra benefit is digesters improve manure nutrient management as solids are separated from liquids making it easier to place nutrients where they’re needed most, addressing the N2O emissions from crop production.

Reinemann adds the biggest economic driver influencing digester adoptions is government energy policies. The upcoming federal election will likely impact this situation.

Looking north for inspiration

Dairies north of the US border have long been invested in on-farm sustainability practices for their future and the environment according to the Dairy Farmers of Canada (DFC) President, David Wiens.

“Over the years we’ve made great strides in reducing the emissions, land, and water required to produce each litre of milk, thanks to advances in agricultural technology and the sector’s ongoing commitment to continuous improvement,” Wiens says. “Dairy cows account for only about 1% of Canada’s total GHG emissions, and the carbon footprint of one litre of Canadian milk is less than half the global average.”

Thanks to innovations in herd management, genetics, feeding, and comfort, the Canadian dairy industry has become more efficient, helping lower its environmental footprint.

“The modern dairy-cow diet is more nutritious and often specially formulated to enhance digestion, which helps increase feed efficiency and milk production,” Wiens says. “It also reduces GHGs associated with methane animals naturally emit during rumination.”

Beyond nutrition, Canadian operations employ a variety of control practices. Innovations such as GPS-enabled smart tractors, on-farm data collection tools, robotic machinery, and other high-tech equipment support sustainable and efficient milk production. Crop rotations, manure management, cover crops, and decreased tillage also contribute.

Additionally, Canadian dairies are incorporating biodigesters to convert manure storage methane into reusable energy such as biogas and renewable natural gas, with the ability to use the manure by-product (digestate) as a natural fertiliser.

Likewise, genetics are accelerating sustainable and best management practices. Breeding cattle for climate resilience and lessening their environmental impact offers a vital opportunity for reduction. The University of Guelph Resilient Dairy Genome Project is researching and assessing new genomic evaluations to identify more feed-efficient, resilient to heat stress, and fertile cows with assistance from the DFC.

The Methane Efficiency genetic evaluation is a recent example of genetic advancements. It delivers the world’s first official genetic evaluation to help producers select for reduced methane emissions without impacting performance levels.

“Farmer's livelihoods rely on the land, and sustainable practices help maintain their future,” Wiens says. “They’re proud of the care they give their cows and continuously work with experts to make the best choices about how their livestock live and eat, their health, and the traits they pass on. This increases productivity and demands fewer resources to produce milk while addressing emissions.”

Nutrition and technology boost reductions

Ermias Kebreab, Associate Dean, College of Agriculture and Environmental Sciences at UC Davis believes from a nutritional perspective, diet alone isn’t the answer as possible cuts only reach the 10 to 15% range.

“The big push of 40 to 60% can only be accomplished through additives and this is why many see them as the next big thing,” Kebreab says.

3-NOP, the most well-known methane-reducing additive, has recently been approved in the US and Canada. Rights-owner, Elanco, will use its vast technological roll-out experience to ensure a quick market impact.

Options like seaweed are also promising but still in the research and trial stages.

“Seaweed has presented some cultivation challenges,” he says. “We’ve much to learn about growing and storing it safely. Our work at UC Davis shows it to be effective up to 80% which is significant. If it’s found safe for animals, humans, and the planet, it will be a part of the solution.”

Genome editing technologies like CRISPR are similarly encouraging. A 7-year UC Davis trial is in the early stages of examining its capabilities.

“We’re trying to understand the microbiome better and identify what we can change and target,” Kebreab says. “We have the tools, but we need to learn more before we apply them and determine if it’s a viable solution.”

Incentives and market response

Kebreab agrees public pressure targeting livestock’s environmental impact is a key driving force for all endeavours. As more incentives are offered to meet agreed-on target numbers, the agricultural community will strive to build sustainability, ensuring farming isn’t harming the environment. Many players are currently attempting to meet their Paris Climate Agreement commitments.

He believes some influences will come from elected parties and officials, but most will be decided by the markets as many large companies such as Danone, Nestle, Starbucks, and MacDonalds have already publicly committed to cutting emissions.

“I don’t think there is any way to back out of this now without ignoring their commitments and creating a negative reaction,” Kebreab says. “They’ll simply be forced to push ahead.”

He explains research and trial investments have been lacking although it is improving. Organisations such as the Global Methane Hub, the Gates Foundation, and increased USDA governmental funding are making a positive difference.

Looking to the future

Reinemann’s view of the future includes further reductions although he doesn’t envision ever reaching net zero. He sees anaerobic digesters becoming more commonplace, especially on larger farms.

“The efficiency of the dairy industry including emission management has strengthened,” Reinemann says. “This will likely continue as I think we’re on the verge of an agricultural technological revolution with automation, AI, and big data.”

Kebreab believes that with the technologies being developed worldwide, industry solutions will be near 25 to 50% reductions, which will be huge.

“There’s no silver bullet for this issue but the industry’s future is bright,” Kebreab says. “We’ll need to employ different methods as conditions demand with separate areas and regions having varying solutions, but we’re moving in the right direction. Many of these factors are business decisions but it's happening faster than before. Much of it hinges on investments and economic incentives from world governments.”

References are available on request.

urn:contentItem:69BY-C5H1-JB14-704H-00000-00Sustainable, climate-resilient feed for livestock2023-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:44:12ZLexisNexisARTICLESustainable, climate-resilient feed for livestockNate Blum

As the world faces the escalating challenges of climate change, the agricultural sector, particularly animal husbandry, is under increasing pressure to adapt. The need for animal feed that can withstand changing weather patterns, rising temperatures, and water scarcity is more pressing than ever.

In this context, sorghum and millet stand out for their resilience and adaptability. Known for their robust nature and ability to thrive in diverse climates, sorghum and millet are emerging as versatile and sustainable feed options that could shape the future of livestock farming. This article delves into the potential of sorghum and millet as animal feed, exploring their unique characteristics, economic bene­fits, and the recent advancements in their cultivation practices that ­contribute to sustainable agriculture and climate resilience.

Natural solution to mitigate climate change

Sorghum and millet, cereal grains native to Africa, have long been celebrated for their remarkable adaptability. Unlike many other crops, sorghum and millet have a natural resistance to drought and heat, making them ideal feed options in the face of the increasing temperatures and water scarcity associated with climate change.

A study published in the scientific journal Naturein 2020 shed light on the unique adaptive capabilities of sorghum. The researchers found that sorghum’s deep root system and efficient water use allow it to survive and even thrive in a variety of environmental conditions. This adaptability is particularly beneficial in regions prone to climate extremes, where traditional feed crops often fail. By providing a reliable harvest even in challenging conditions, sorghum and millet play a crucial role in ensuring global livestock feed security in the face of climate change.

Stimulating economies in arid regions

In addition to their environmental benefits, sorghum and millet also have significant economic potential. In arid and semi-arid regions, where traditional feed crops struggle to survive, sorghum and millet can flourish, providing a valuable source of income for farmers. This is particularly important in these regions, where agriculture often forms the backbone of the local economy.

The economic potential of sorghum and millet is further amplified by their versatility. They can be used as feed for livestock, an important consideration in regions where pasture may be scarce. This versatility opens up multiple markets for sorghum and millet, stimulating local economies and providing a sustainable livelihood for farmers.

Enhancing ­sustainability

The potential of sorghum and millet as sustainable feed crops is further enhanced by recent advancements in cultivation practices. Researchers across the globe have been exploring the genetic diversity of these grains to breed varieties with improved traits. These traits include increased yield, improved nutritional content for animals, and enhanced resistance to pests and diseases.

Increased yield means that farmers can produce more feed from the same amount of land, a crucial factor in feeding the world’s growing livestock population. Improved nutritional content makes sorghum and millet a more valuable feed source, contributing to livestock health and productivity. Enhanced resistance to pests and diseases reduces the need for chemical pesticides, contributing to the sustainability of their cultivation.

These advances thus not only increase the productivity of sorghum and millet crops but also contribute to their sustainability. By reducing the need for chemical inputs, these advances help to protect the environment and promote biodiversity. Furthermore, by developing varieties that are more resistant to pests and diseases, researchers are helping to ensure that sorghum and millet can continue to provide a reliable source of feed and income in the face of future challenges.

Robust option for the future

Sorghum and millet represent a promising solution to the challenges of climate change and sustainability in livestock farming. Their natural adaptability, economic potential, and the ongoing advances in their cultivation practices make them robust feed options for the future. As we continue to navigate the uncertainties of climate change, feed crops such as sorghum and millet will be crucial in ensuring livestock feed security and sustainable agricultural practices but also contribute to broader efforts to combat climate change and promote sustainability.

urn:contentItem:5VCJ-MMR1-DXG5-Y17V-00000-00Wheat not ready for climate change2019-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:44:12ZLexisNexisARTICLEWheat not ready for climate changeEmmy Koeleman

Food security relies on the resilience of staple food crops to climatic variability and extremes, but the climate resilience of European wheat is unknown. A group of European researchers therefore looked into this further and wrote down the results in the paper: ­Decline in climate resilience of European wheat, published in PNAS (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences). In this study, the researchers quantified the response diversity of wheat in nine European countries (Finland, Denmark, Germany, Belgium, Czech Republic, France, Slovakia, Italy, and Spain). The researchers identified the variation in response diversity on farmers’ fields and demonstrated the relation to climate resilience. The entire cultivar yield data set comprised of 100,985 observations. The data show a decline in the response diversity of wheat in farmers’ fields in most European countries after 2002–2009. Per country, the situation per response diversity differs a bit or started later.

The authors defined deserts (low diversity) and hotspots (high diversity). The Czech Republic showed the sharpest decline in response diversity since 2002. Also for the other countries a decline is seen, but the year it started differently per country. This assessment suggests that current breeding programmes and cultivar selection practices do not sufficiently prepare for climatic uncertainty and variability. Therefore, more research is needed to advance the understanding of the genetic basis to yield and quality response to weather. The researchers further state that the national action plans and the Common Agricultural Policy of the European Union are instrumental in removing the current disincentives and introducing new incentives and regulation for diversity in crop responses to climatic uncertainties. However, the authors address that regulation needs to imply sufficient flexibility to allow adaptive management and continuous collective learning.

urn:contentItem:6DMP-51X1-F16X-F0CW-00000-00Nabat, de nieuwe klimaattech-venture van Abu Dhabi, maakt gebruik van AI en robotica om mangroves te herstellen en klimaatbestendigheid te bevorderen2024-12-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:44:12ZLexisNexisNabat, de nieuwe klimaattech-venture van Abu Dhabi, maakt gebruik van AI en robotica om mangroves te herstellen en klimaatbestendigheid te bevorderenNieuwe start-up van de Advanced Technology Research Council's VentureOne maakt gebruik van AI en autonome robotica voor het behoud van natuurlijke ecosystemen, te beginnen met mangroves om daarna naar andere habitats uit te breidenABU DHABI, Verenigde Arabische Emiraten

De Advanced Technology Research Council's VentureOne heeft Nabat onthuld, een nieuwe klimaattech-venture voor het behoud en het herstel van mangroves en andere ecosystemen in de regio aan de hand van AI en robotica, tijdens de International Mangrove Conservation and Restoration Conference in Abu Dhabi.

Dit persbericht bevat multimedia. Bekijk hier het volledige persbericht: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20241211728260/nl/

Nabat demonstreerde hun geavanceerde technologie, waaronder drones, door AI aangestuurde software en flexibele zaaimechanismen, die men de komende zeven jaar zal gebruiken voor het behoud en het herstel van duizenden hectares mangroves in de Verenigde Arabische Emiraten. Mangrovebossen slaan tot vijf keer meer koolstof op dan bomen van een regenwoud en zijn een vitaal onderdeel van het ecosysteem van de Verenigde Arabische Emiraten, cruciaal in de strijd tegen de klimaatverandering die in de hele wereld wordt gevoerd.

"Nabat vormt een voorbeeld van hoe de VAE geavanceerde technologie benut ten behoeve van de mensheid," verklaart Zijne Excellentie Faisal Al Bannai, secretaris-generaal van de Advanced Technology Research Council (ATRC). "Door innovatie en wetenschap met elkaar te versmelten, leveren we inspanningen om ecosystemen te herstellen, biodiversiteit te bevorderen en klimaatbestendigheid te verstevigen, om ons land sneller op netto-nul te kunnen brengen."

"Technologie en natuur worden vaak als haaks op elkaar beschouwd, maar als we technologie met op wetenschap gebaseerd onderzoek combineren om kritieke problemen op te lossen, kan technologie een van de krachtigste bondgenoten van de natuur worden," zegt Dr. Najwa Aaraj, CEO van de Technology Innovation Institute, de tak toegepaste wetenschappen van ATRC, en ontwikkelaar van de technologie achter Nabat. "Ons systeem helpt om diverse kritieke uitdagingen in verband met natuurbehoud aan te pakken. Een van de belangrijkste uitdagingen is het verzamelen van gegevens. Er bestaan geen twee ecosystemen die identiek zijn, voor elk ecosysteem is een gepersonaliseerde, op gegevens gebaseerde benadering noodzakelijk."

De AI en robotica van Nabat staan in voor nauwkeurig in kaart brengen, zaaien en opvolgen, om op die manier een behoud en herstel te verzekeren dat op de unieke, complexe behoeften van elk ecosysteem is afgestemd. In tegenstelling tot de traditionele aanplant van mangrovebossen, die zeer arbeidsintensief is en zelfs de omringende ecosystemen kan schaden, raakt het systeem van Nabat de habitats zo min mogelijk.

Tijdens het in kaart brengen, verschaft de technologie van Nabat grote hoeveelheden gegevens over de bodem, maar ook over de dichtheid, de hoogte en de hydrologie van natuurlijke habitats. Het zaaimechanisme met drones maakt gebruik van geoptimaliseerde trajectplanning en flexibele zaaipatronen om te verzekeren dat de zaadjes op een exacte plaats worden geplant en alleen als zij daar nodig zijn. Het systeem omvat ook monitoringcapaciteiten om te kunnen verzekeren dat de geplante bomen veilig groeien.

Nabats technologie werkt ook in moeilijk te bereiken, afgelegen gebieden, zodat de inspanningen voor behoud en herstel op efficiënte wijze op schaal kunnen worden gebracht terwijl de kosten hiervoor tot een minimum worden beperkt.

Reda Nidhakou, waarnemend CEO van VentureOne, het moederbedrijf van Nabat, licht toe: "Kernidee van VentureOne is start-ups lanceren die baanbrekende technologie aan de wereld voorstellen. De technologie met de grootste waarde is niet alleen innovatief, efficiënt of winstgevend. Het allerbelangrijkste is dat het een meetbare positieve impact heeft. Het was een voorrecht om hand in hand te mogen werken met het team en ons ruimere ecosysteem om op een dergelijke fundamentele wijze te helpen timmeren aan de weg naar duurzaamheid van de VAE."

Terwijl de initiële focus van het bedrijf op mangroves in de VAE is gericht, zijn er ook plannen om naar andere delen van de regio uit te breiden en bijkomende ecosystemen te dienen, zoals woestijngebieden, akkerland, wouden en koraalriffen.

*Bron:AETOSWire

Deze bekendmaking is officieel geldend in de originele brontaal. Vertalingen zijn slechts als leeshulp bedoeld en moeten worden vergeleken met de tekst in de brontaal, die als enige rechtsgeldig is.

urn:contentItem:6G9X-3HD3-RV5P-14C1-00000-00Klimaatweerbaarheid Bonaire gemeten...2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:44:12ZLexisNexisNEWSKlimaatweerbaarheid Bonaire gemeten...

Van onze correspondent Kralendijk - Het veldwerk voor het Stinapa Climate Resilience Project, in samenwerking met Florida State University (FSU), Lenfest Ocean Program en RassterLab,...

Van onze correspondent Kralendijk - Het veldwerk voor het Stinapa Climate Resilience Project, in samenwerking met Florida State University (FSU), Lenfest Ocean Program en RassterLab, is in volle gang. Het project is bedoeld om te begrijpen wat er precies g...

Van onze correspondent Kralendijk - Het veldwerk voor het Stinapa Climate Resilience Project, in samenwerking met Florida State University (FSU), Lenfest Ocean Program en RassterLab, is in volle gang. Het project is bedoeld om te begrijpen wat er precies gebeurt en te helpen bij het vinden van oplossingen voor de gevolgen van klimaatverandering in het Bonaire National Marine Park. ,,We onderzoeken hoe klimaatverandering het mariene milieu van Bonaire beïnvloedt door stressoren zoals hoge temperaturen die koraalverbleking, ziekten en recreatieve effecten, te evalueren. Ons doel is om vast te stellen welke gebieden meer worden blootgesteld aan of juist beschermd zijn tegen stressfactoren om de toekomstige gezondheid van het rif te voorspellen”, aldus Stinapa. De verkregen informatie zal worden gebruikt in de lopende ecologische monitoringprogramma's om te helpen bij een betere detectie van en reactie op klimaatveranderingsgebeurtenissen. Acties die worden ondernomen zijn het in kaart brengen van de kwetsbaarheid voor het klimaat om gebieden met een hoog risico te identificeren, een gap-analyse uitvoeren van de ecologische monitoringprogramma's van Stinapa, workshops organiseren voor belanghebbenden om lokale perspectieven en kennis te begrijpen en het ontwikkelen van managementaanbevelingen voor het Bonaire National Marine Park. Er worden op dit moment Hobo Data Loggers gebruikt om de watertemperatuur op verschillende dieptes te monitoren, op 20, 12 en 6 meter diepte en aan de oppervlakte. ,,Deze geweldige onderhoudsarme sensoren helpen ons om kritische gegevens te volgen, maar ze moeten handmatig worden gereinigd en gelost.” Een speciaal team is hier op dit moment mee bezig.

urn:contentItem:6G5S-3963-RSPR-T0YP-00000-00<published>2025-07-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-09-15T22:44:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="nl"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:dateline><location>PARMA, Italië</location></nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> Barilla opent officieel de inschrijvingen voor <emphasis typeStyle="bf">Good Food Makers 2025</emphasis>, zijn open innovatieprogramma voor startups en innovatieve bedrijven die zich richten op het creëren van een duurzamer en meer verbonden voedselsysteem. </p><p> Het programma, nu in de <emphasis typeStyle="bf">zevende editie</emphasis>, verwelkomt een nieuw opzet - <emphasis typeStyle="bf">Good Food Makers - ECOSYSTEM</emphasis> - ontwikkeld in samenwerking met <emphasis typeStyle="bf">Almacube</emphasis>, de innovatiehub van de Universiteit van Bologna en Confindustria Emilia. Het doel van dit jaar is om een echt innovatie-ecosysteem te creëren door <emphasis typeStyle="bf">Barilla's partners in de waardeketen</emphasis> te betrekken en de implementatie van opkomende technologieën te versnellen. </p><p> Drie geselecteerde startups gaan deelnemen aan een <emphasis typeStyle="bf">vier weken durend co-ontwikkelingstraject</emphasis> met professionals en partnerbedrijven van Barilla, waarbij ze zij aan zij werken aan impactvolle oplossingen voor de hele voedselketen - van het veld tot op het bord. Aanmeldingen kunnen worden ingediend tot <emphasis typeStyle="bf">eind juli</emphasis>. Het programma loopt van <emphasis typeStyle="bf">september tot januari 2026 </emphasis>en wordt afgesloten met de <emphasis typeStyle="bf">Innovatiedag</emphasis>. </p><p><emphasis typeStyle="it">"Good Food Makers weerspiegelt onze toewijding aan open innovatie die echte waarde genereert,"</emphasis> aldus <emphasis typeStyle="bf">Claudia Berti</emphasis>, hoofd Open Innovation bij Barilla. <emphasis typeStyle="it">"Deze speciale Ecosystem-editie stelt ons in staat om samen met strategische partners impactvolle oplossingen te creëren die belangrijke uitdagingen zoals duurzaamheid en digitale transformatie aanpakken."</emphasis></p><p><emphasis typeStyle="bf">De uitdagingen voor 2025 zijn:</emphasis></p><list><listItem><label>•</label><bodyText><p> AgTech for Climate Resilience (met Open Fields): technologieën om de basilicumteelt te verbeteren en wilde kruiden op duurzame manier te beheren. </p></bodyText></listItem><listItem><label>•</label><bodyText><p> New Frontiers in Detection (met Bizerba): geavanceerde oplossingen voor kwaliteit en precisie in detectiesystemen voor productielijnen. </p></bodyText></listItem><listItem><label>•</label><bodyText><p> Best on Shelf (met Conad Nord Ovest): tools om de productzichtbaarheid, schapaanwezigheid en winkelervaring in de winkel te verbeteren. </p></bodyText></listItem></list><p> Sinds 2019 <emphasis typeStyle="bf">hebben meer dan 900 startups uit 25 landen</emphasis> zich aangemeld, waarvan er al <emphasis typeStyle="bf">26 zijn geselecteerd</emphasis> voor samenwerking. Opvallende samenwerkingsverbanden zijn onder andere: </p><list><listItem><label>•</label><bodyText><p> Connecting Food, dat blockchain-gebaseerde traceerbaarheid mogelijk maakte voor de toeleveringsketen voor vers basilicum van Barilla; </p></bodyText></listItem><listItem><label>•</label><bodyText><p> Nosh Biofoods, dat duurzame, voedingsrijke ingrediënten creëert door middel van fermentatie; </p></bodyText></listItem><listItem><label>•</label><bodyText><p> Manual.to, dat fabriekstrainingsprocessen vereenvoudigt met een digitaal platform dat nu wordt gebruikt in de fabriek van Barilla in Cremona; </p></bodyText></listItem><listItem><label>•</label><bodyText><p> Voxpopme, dat AI-gestuurde consumenteninzichten levert die worden gebruikt in het onderzoek van Barilla. </p></bodyText></listItem></list><p> In 2024 investeerde Barilla <emphasis typeStyle="bf">(EURO) 50 miljoen dollar in R&D</emphasis> en breidde het zijn hoofdkantoor in Parma uit tot een centrum van 12.000 m² voor innovatie en technische expertise. </p><p> Voor meer informatie en om deel te nemen: <url normalizedValue="http://www.goodfoodmakers.it">www.goodfoodmakers.it</url></p><p> Deze bekendmaking is officieel geldend in de originele brontaal. Vertalingen zijn slechts als leeshulp bedoeld en moeten worden vergeleken met de tekst in de brontaal, die als enige rechtsgeldig is. </p><p> Bekijk het oorspronkelijke bericht op businesswire.com: <url normalizedValue="https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20250702994851/nl/">https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20250702994851/nl/</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><contact><bodyText><p><br/><br/>CONTACT: Elena Botturi: , +31642472860 </p></bodyText></contact></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">BWNED-20250702994851</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">BWNED2025</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:6G5S-3963-RSPR-T0YP-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">300617</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2025-07-02</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="510"/><timeReceived>12:20 PM GMT</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2025 Business Wire, Inc.
